resources.string: How to view Google Maps locations in other map apps
Share a location from Google Maps app or from your web browser.
Screenshot of Google Maps’ share screen
Choose %1$s and %2$s will let you open the location in any installed map app.
Configure Android to open links to Google Maps in alternative maps (optional)
First, go to Settings → Apps → Maps → Open by default and turn off the opening of links in this app.
Screenshot of Google Maps’ Open by default settings
Then go to Settings → Apps → %1$s → Open by default, turn on the opening of links in this app, and tap Add links.
Screenshot of %1$s’s Open by default settings

Select at least <tt>maps.google.com</tt> and <tt>maps.app.goo.gl</tt>. If some links are grayed out, other Google apps are set to open them by default. You can find these apps and turn off the opening of links for them, like we did for Google Maps.
Select %1$s when sharing from Google Maps.
Screenshot of Google Maps’ share screen
Or open %1$s and paste your Google Maps link there.
Screenshot of %1$s’s geo: link conversion form
Paste a Google Maps link here
%1s supports many Google Maps URL formats. If you still find a link that doesn’t work, please report an issue.
The link <tt>%1$s</tt> doesn’t contain coordinates or place name. %2$s needs to connect to Google to get the information.
The link <tt>%1$s</tt> doesn’t contain coordinates. %2$s can connect to Google to get them, or it can instead create a geo: link leading to a search by place name.
To share geo: links, you need to allow Other permissions → Display pop-up windows while running in the background to %1$s.

%1$s is a free and open-source app distributed under the GPL 3.0 or later license.


You can find the code at GitHub, where you can also report issues.


Your feedback is welcome. You can reach me at jakub@jakubvalenta.cz.
How it works and privacy considerations

%1$s converts Google Maps links into geo: links that can be opened by other map apps. To create a geo: link, geographic coordinates are required. %1$s extracts them from the Google Maps URL.


However, not all Google Maps URLs include coordinates. In such cases, %1$s will prompt you for permission to connect to Google and retrieve the coordinates from either HTTP headers or the HTML document of the link.


More precisely, there are three scenarios how %1$s converts a Google Maps URL into a geo: URI:


1.


If the Google Maps URL already contains geographic coordinates (for example https://www.google.com/maps/place/Central+Park/data=!3d44.4490541!4d26.0888398), then it’s parsed and no request to Google’s servers is made.


2.


If the Google Maps URL doesn’t contain geographic coordinates (for example https://www.google.com/maps/place/Central+Park/), then %1$s asks you if it can connect to Google.


If you allow connecting to Google, then %1$s makes an HTTP GET request to Google Maps and parses the coordinates from the HTML response. You can imagine it as curl https://www.google.com/maps/place/Central+Park/ | grep -E \'/@[0-9.,-]+\'.


If you don’t allow connecting to Google, then %1$s creates a geo: link with a place search term (for example geo:0,0?q=Central%%20Park).


3.


If the Google Maps URL is a short link (for example https://maps.app.goo.gl/TmbeHMiLEfTBws9EA), then %1$s asks you if it can connect to Google.


If you allow connecting to Google, then %1$s makes an HTTP HEAD request to the short link and reads the full link from the response headers. You can imagine it as curl -I https://maps.app.goo.gl/TmbeHMiLEfTBws9EA | grep location:. Then %1$s continues with scenario 1 or 2, depending on whether the full link contains coordinates or not. In case of scenario 2, another connection to Google will be made, but this time without asking.


If you don’t allow connecting to Google, then %1$s cancels the creation of the geo: link.



To permanently allow or deny connecting to Google instead of always asking (the default), go to the app’s Preferences.
Compatibility with the GMaps WV app
You don’t need %1$s when using the GMaps WV app, because that app already produces geo: links. So you can directly share a location from GMaps WV with another map app.
To support short Google Maps links, and to get coordinates from Google Maps web page when the link doesn’t contain them, %1$s can connect to Google. You can find more information on the FAQ screen.
Which version of the app was last run?
Can’t share geo: link without permission
No app that can open geo: links is installed
Copied geo: link to clipboard unchanged
This link is not supported without connecting to Google
Failed to fetch Google Maps page
